phrases.text: Xẻ ván xẻ ván ới hỡi cho dày dày lại cho dày chứ anh thời về xẻ ván ới hỡi cho dày
phrases.english: split plank split plank (exclamation) o (vocative) for/to thick thick again/come for/to thick particle (emphasis) you (older brother/male) time return split plank (exclamation) o (vocative) for/to thick

culturalContext.description: As the opening phrase, this establishes the song's emotional tone and invites audience engagement.
facts: Northern Vietnamese music is characterized by refined, softer dynamics, high tessitura
Opening phrases in Vietnamese folk songs often use vocatives (ơi, này) to grab attention before the narrative begins
Vietnamese musical phrases typically follow speech tone patterns - rising tones matched with rising pitches
The pentatonic scale (5-note) is fundamental to Vietnamese folk music, avoiding Western semitone tensions
culturalContext.musicalContext: As the opening phrase, it establishes the tonal center and introduces the melodic motif that will be varied throughout.

phrases.text: Bắc cầu là cầu qua cái con sông Cái cái ơ cái a cái ả tang tình đón thầy mẹ sang
phrases.english: North bridge is/be bridge cross/over classifier classifier (animals) river classifier classifier oh classifier (vocative) classifier ả [?] mourning/sad love/feelings đón [?] teacher mother cross over

culturalContext.description: Rivers ("sông") hold deep significance in Vietnamese culture - the Red River shaped Northern civilization, the Mekong defines the South. River crossings mark major life transitions.
facts: Vietnamese civilization developed around major rivers: Red River (Sông Hồng) in North, Mekong (Cửu Long) in South
River ferries (đò sông) appear frequently in folk songs as settings for chance romantic encounters
Northern Vietnamese music is characterized by refined, softer dynamics, high tessitura
Vietnamese musical phrases typically follow speech tone patterns - rising tones matched with rising pitches

phrases.text: Thầy mẹ là mẹ sang trước cái ơ cái a cái ả tang tình
phrases.english: teacher mother is/be mother cross over before/in front classifier oh classifier (vocative) classifier ả [?] mourning/sad love/feelings

culturalContext.description: This narrative phrase contributes to the song's narrative structure and emotional arc, typical of Northern folk traditions.
facts: Northern Vietnamese music is characterized by refined, softer dynamics, high tessitura
Vietnamese musical phrases typically follow speech tone patterns - rising tones matched with rising pitches
The pentatonic scale (5-note) is fundamental to Vietnamese folk music, avoiding Western semitone tensions
Đàn tranh (16-string zither) arrangements of folk songs are 20th century innovations - originals were vocal
culturalContext.musicalContext: Positioned at the song's midpoint, this phrase likely marks a structural pivot or climax in the narrative.

phrases.text: anh em ta ráy ức hự sang sau I í sau chứ thời sang sau
phrases.english: you (older brother/male) you (younger) I/we ráy [?] choke/억 hự [?] cross over after/behind (particle) í [?] after/behind particle (emphasis) time cross over after/behind

culturalContext.description: As the closing phrase, this provides resolution and often returns to opening themes for circular structure.
facts: Northern Vietnamese music is characterized by refined, softer dynamics, high tessitura
Vietnamese musical phrases typically follow speech tone patterns - rising tones matched with rising pitches
The pentatonic scale (5-note) is fundamental to Vietnamese folk music, avoiding Western semitone tensions
Đàn tranh (16-string zither) arrangements of folk songs are 20th century innovations - originals were vocal
culturalContext.musicalContext: As the closing phrase, it typically returns to the tonic note and may quote the opening melody for circular structure.
